Detailed Description

Module Voice Recognition (VR) is Apoxi's API layer which provides access to voice recognition funcionality of underlying voice recognition engines. This API is meant to be independent of the used voice recognition engine.

Clarification of terms

Some terms used in this documentation should be clarified before to avoid missunderstanding.
  • Client: any software that uses this VR interfaces, most probably applications in MMI
  • Template, VR Template: Data that is used by the VR engine for recognition. Clients work with VR templates only in terms of using their unique ids.

Purpose and design goals

  • VR engine independent access to VR engines
  • Easy start of training and recognition processes
  • Easy handling of used VR template data, clients should not have to bother with the data itself

Concepts

  • Use of single handler to trigger recognition or training
    • class VrHandler
  • Results deliverd using messages
    • various message classes

Using voice recognition

The use of VR is actually quite easy. First of all, the concept of VR template must be explained.

VR templates

Each VR template represents one word VR is able to recognize. There are two classes of templates:

  • Predefined templates which are used for speaker independent recognition (e.g. digit dialing).
  • Trained templates which are created by either vocal training or by using G2A. Templates trained by vocal training are speaker dependent, G2A templates are speaker independent. Any trained template is always related to the client which started the training.

Each template has an unique id. The client has to work with this ids only. In no case, the client has to deal with the binary template data, the various templates consist of. All issues according storing or loading this data is done by the Apoxi VR layer. Nevertheless, the client has to know what should happen when a certain template has been recognized. Apoxi VR only provides the id of the recognized templates. The actions to be taken (e.g. dialing a number) have to be executed by the client. For predefined commands Apoxi VR is able to tell which command is behind an id. For trained commands, the client has to have this information by itself.

Doing a recognition

A recognition is always done for a set of templates, never on all existing templates, since that would cause useless performance problems. For example, for an phonebook client it makes no sense, that single digits are recognized. It only needs one of the names of it's entries to be recognized. So before a recognition can be done, the client has to tell VR, which templates should included in the recognition process. This is done by providing a set of template ids.The set of templates is built either by the client it self (out of a local database) or provided by Apoxi VR (for predefined templates).

Before the actual recognition can start, some initialization of the VR engine has to be done by Apoxi VR (the client has to do nothing for that). As soon as the VR engine is ready to start the actual recognition, the client receives a VrPromptMsg. This indicates that the client should prompt the user, that (s)he should start speaking. After prompting is complete (e.g. a beep sound has been played), the client indicates to Apoxi VR that recording of the voice can be started.

While recognition is active (and the user is speaking) results might already be received by the client. The id of each recognized template is sent to the client with a VrResultMsg. The last result is indicated by a flag in this message. The last result also indicates the end of the recognition process.

Training a speaker dependent template

If a client has the need for recognition of commands not covered by the predefined templates, a new one can be recorded. When a client starts a training, it receives an VrPromptMsg as soon as the VR engine is ready to record. Then the client has to indicate to the user, that he/she should start speaking. When this prompting is completed the client indicates to Apoxi VR that recording of the voice can be started.

If everything went ok for training, the client receives a VrTrainingResultMsg containing the id of the newly created template. The client is now responsible for keeping the information what semantics is represented by this command's id (e.g. a phonebook application has to store which entry this id belongs to).

The G2A feature

Some voice recognition engines support a feature called G2A. This enables an application to build an template for recognition from a string. E.g. if a WAP page contains a link and the link is represented by a word like "News", the WAP application could turn "News" into a speaker independent training and let the user navigate using voice recognition.

Like at training of spoken templates, the result id is delivered to the client in an VrTrainingResultMsg. The client again is responsible for keeping track of the semantics of the template. Also the client should be aware, that no longer needed templates are discarded, otherwise the system could get overflown by unused templates.

Managing existing templates

AX VR supports a pile of managing functions to manipulate the set of templates in the system.

Retrieve all templates of a client Delete templates of a client Retrieve sets of predefined template ids for several tasks Translate a predefined template into a command Playback trained templates

Retrieving template sets

To make use of predefined templates, the client doesn't have to know which ids belong to predefined commands. The client simple retrieves a set of ids of predefined commands from AX VR for a special purpose. For now a set of predefined ids for digit dialing can be retrieved. This might be subject of extension in the future. The set contains all ids of templates necessary for the given purpose. E.g. digit dialing contains the numbers '0'-'9', Dial, Cancel and Delete.

To translate the results of the recognition (which will be one or more ids) back into the command which has to be executed, AX VR provides a function that maps the id of a predefined template to commands.

Deleting templates

Templates of a client can be deleted all at once or seperately. To avoid conflicts, the name of the client has to be given for deleting. This should avoid, a client accidentally deleting templates of other clients.

Playback

For speaker dependent templats, also the PCM data recorded at training is stored in the system. This PCM data can be played at any time.

enum VrHandler::VrCommandSet [inherited]
 

Sets of predefined commands.

Several sets of template ids for predefined commands are there:

  • Digits: digits 0-9
  • DigitDialing: digits 0-9, Dial, Cancel, Clear
  • Complete: all known predefined commands (currently the same as DigitDialing)
Enumerator:
Digits 
DigitDialing 
Complete 

enum VrHandler::VrRecognitionMode [inherited]
 

Recognition modes.

Currently two recognition modes are supported

  • IsolatedWord: only one template out of the given set is recognized
  • ConnectedWord: one or more templates are recognized as the user speaks
Enumerator:
IsolatedWord 
ConnectedWord

VrHandler::VrApiRc VrHandler::Abort (   )  [inherited]
 

Abort currently ongoing training or recognition process. This method does a hard abort of any ongoing process.

Returns:
VrSuccess if operation was successful, error code otherwise

void VrHandler::CreateTemplate (  const WString &  client_name,
const WString &  text
)  [inherited]
 

Create template based on a given string using G2A. With G2A speaker independent templates can be created out of a given text. This text must be between 3 and 40 characters long.

Parameters:
client_name String representing the client
text Source for VR template (min 3 chars, max 40 chars)

VrHandler::VrApiRc VrHandler::GetAppTemplates (  const WString &  client_name,
Vector< UINT16 > &  template_ids
)  [inherited]
 

Return templates of a client, client_name acts as key The ids of the templates belonging to the given client are added to the given vector. The vector must be initialised. It may contain ids before. Template ids are just added to the vector, the vector must be initialised before.

Parameters:
client_name String representing the client
template_ids Initialised vector to hold the ids
Returns:
VrSuccess if operation was successful, error code otherwise

VrHandler::VrCommand VrHandler::GetCommand (  UINT16  template_id  )  [inherited]
 

Return the command behind a predefined template id.

Parameters:
template_id Template id to be resolved to predefined command
Returns:
VrCommand represented by template_id, TrainedCommand if id of trained command InvalidCommand for invalid ids

VrHandler::VrApiRc VrHandler::GetCommandTemplates (  VrCommandSet  set,
Vector< UINT16 > &  template_ids
)  [inherited]
 

Return templates for a set of fixed commands.

This returns a set of template ID's for a set of commands. There may be (and usually is) more than one template for a command. If there are are speaker dependent templates for the command, they are also included, regardless of which application has trained the template

Parameters:
set VrCommandSet which shall be put into the vector
template_ids Initialised vector to hold the ids
Returns:
VrSuccess if operation was successful, error code otherwise

VrHandlerId

VrHandler::VrApiRc VrHandler::InitVr (   )  [inherited]
 

Initialize Voice Recognition.

This initializes the Voice Recognition. Basic parameters are set at the VR engine.

BOOLEAN VrHandler::IsSupported (  VrProperty  property  )  [inherited]
 

Check if current VR engine supports a function. This method checks if the used VR engine supports a certain function or not.

Parameters:
property Property which availability should be checked
Returns:
TRUE if property is supported

VrHandler::VrApiRc VrHandler::PlayTemplate (  UINT16  template_id  )  [inherited]
 

Playback trained template.

If the template id belongs to a not-trained template (i.e. there is no PCM data stored) for the template, an error will be produced.

The playback is done asynchronous. This method only triggers playback. The end of playback is indicated by a VrPlaybackFinishedMsg sent to the client. This message contains the id of the template that was played.

Parameters:
template_id Id of template to be played.
Returns:
VrSuccess if operation was successful, error code otherwise

VrHandler::VrApiRc VrHandler::RemoveAllTemplates (  const WString &  client_name  )  [inherited]
 

Delete all templates belonging to a client.

All templates of a client are removed and the according files are erased.

Parameters:
client_name String representing the client
Returns:
VrSuccess if operation was successful, error code otherwise

VrHandler::VrApiRc VrHandler::RemoveTemplate (  const WString &  client_name,
UINT16  template_id
)  [inherited]
 

Remove template.

The template is only removed if the template belongs to the given client. Removal of templates of other clients shall be prevented with this restriction. All files belonging to the template are erased.

Parameters:
client_name String representing the client
template_id Id of template to remove
Returns:
VrSuccess if operation was successful, error code otherwise

void VrHandler::Reset (   )  [protected, inherited]
 

void VrHandler::StartRecognition (  const Vector< UINT16 > &  id_set,
VrRecognitionMode  mode = ConnectedWord,
UINT16  max_time = 700,
UINT32  max_silence = 80
)  [inherited]
 

Start recognition for a set of templates Kicks off an actual recognition process.

Parameters:
id_set Vector containing the ids of the templates for the recognition
mode Recognition mode for this recognition process
max_time Max. time in ms the recognition (i.e. the part where voice is actually recorded) should last. After this time the recognition is finished even if the user continues speaking.
max_silence Max. length of a speaking pause in ms the user may take. If the user stops speaking longer than max_silence, recognition is finished.

void VrHandler::StartRecording (   )  [inherited]
 

Starts recording for training or recognition after prompt. Starts voice recording for the currently ongoing recognition or training process. This method has to be called by the client after prompting the user to start speaking is done.

void VrHandler::StartTraining (  const WString &  client_name  )  [inherited]
 

Start training for a user defined command.

After the engine is ready for recording, a VrPromptMsg is sent to the client, who triggered the training. The client has to call StartRecording() when prompting to the user is done. The result id is delivered using a VrTrainingResultMsg and it is added to the store of templates of the given client.

Parameters:
client_name String representing the client
Returns:
VrSuccess if operation was successful, error code otherwise

BOOLEAN VrHandler::Startup (   )  [static, inherited]
 

Called by Stack Control on system startup to do some init stuff.

VrHandler::VrApiRc VrHandler::StopRecognition (   )  [inherited]
 

Stop repeated mode recognition after prompt request, feature not yet finished Stops currently ongoing recognition process. This method can be called by a client whilst an recognition process to stop it (e.g. if the received results are sufficent).

Returns:
VrSuccess if operation was successful, error code otherwise

Creates a new handler instance. This constructor creates a new instance of VrHandler. The VR module is initialized if not done before.
